Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Yet Ouch Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Yet O. has been selected as village bank loan group leader by fourteen people who are located in Srae Pou village in Takeo province. All the members make up a village bank loan, and they will each use a small part of the loan for different purposes. 

Mrs. Yet O. was born in 1972. She is a silk cloth seller at her local market. Since her business is going well she wants to expand. So to improve this business, Mrs. Yet O. is seeking a loan to buy more silk cloth for resale. Her husband, Mr. Phong Choub, is a farmer who owns one-hectare of land to cultivate rice on to sell to support his family and he is a cow middleman, too. 

Mrs. Yet O.  is the mother of three children, one of whom is a construction worker, while the others are attending local public school.

loans.use: To buy more silk cloth for resale

loans.name: Oem

texts.en: Mrs. Oem S. is 48 years old and is a villager who lives in Smaong village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns 1-hectare of land to cultivate rice on. Aside from being a farmer, she is also a pig breeder who wants to earn a small income by selling duck eggs to support her family. To expand her duck breeding, Mrs. Oem S. decided to ask for a loan to buy rice and duck feed for duck breeding. Her husband, Mr.  Chorn S., is a construction worker where he can receive a small salary to help support his family. Mrs. Oem S. is the mother of four children who all are students and also support their mother's businesses.

loans.use: To buy rice and duck feed

loans.name: Pichet

texts.en:
Mr. Pichet S., is 27 years old and his wife, Mrs. Chamroeun Oeun, is 25 years old. They have been married since 2003 and have two children: one son and one daughter, both of them still young. The family lives on an Island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. Pichet was not available for the photo so his wife is shown instead.

Pichet has been a wooden-house constructor for four years, working in his village and in the nearby districts. His wife is a silk weaver. He does not have enough construction materials to work, so he is applying for his first loan of $700 to purchase construction materials for his business. He will also use part of the loan to buy silk materials for his wife’s weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase construction materials for his business and silk materials for his wife’s weaving business

loans.name: Sohrab John

texts.en:
Sohrab John R. is from the village of Brgy. Palabotan, Dupax de Sur, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 45 years old. Sohrab John is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Sohrab John owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Sohrab John has been engaged in his business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP when he sells his mature animal.

In 2010, Sohrab John joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Sohrab John is requesting a loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be the first loan taken out by Sohrab John from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Sokha

texts.en: Mrs. Sokha P. is 40 years old and is a villager who lives in Samna Khmau village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice on to earn her living. For this farm, Mrs. Sokha P. does not have any oxen to plow her soil, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy two oxen to plow her farm. Her husband, Mr. Thy Soem, is a construction worker and he can receive a little salary to support his family. This couple has five children; one is a seamstress in a garment factory, and one is a farmer, while the other three are students in the local school.

loans.use: To buy two oxen to plow her  farm

loans.name: Yun

texts.en: Mrs. Yun N. is 52 years old and is a villager who lives in Samna Khmau village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. N. Nut, are farmers who own 2-hectares of land to cultivate rice on to earn their living. Mrs. Yun N. now is requesting a loan to purchase a motorcycle for transport. This couple has six children; two are seamstresses in the garment factory, one is a car wash laborer, and one is a laborer at the Thai border while the other two are students in the local school.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle

loans.name: Yorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Yorn T., age 48, is a widow with three sons and two daughters. Two of her sons are construction workers, one child is a garment factory worker and the other two are in school. Yorn sells vegetables. She lives about fifteen kilometers south of Phnom Penh. 

The wall of Yorn’s house is old and she wants to repair it, but she does not have the money. Therefore, she is applying for her first loan of $250 in order to make the repair.

loans.use: To repair the wall of her house

loans.name: Eddiemar

texts.en:
Eddiemar P. is from the town of Bambang, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 48 years old. Eddiemar is married and has 3 children. To make a living, Eddiemar owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Eddiemar has been engaged in his business for over 25 years and earns approximately 40,000 PHP per harvest.

In 2010, Eddiemar joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Eddiemar is requesting a loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the first loan taken out by Eddiemar from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of his family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Vanny

texts.en: Mrs. Vanny E. is 45 years old and is a villager who lives in Prambei Mom village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice on to earn her living. Her husband, Mr. Sok Chann, is a construction worker and he can receive a small salary to support his family. Because her husband's work place is far from their home, Mrs. Vanny E. decided to ask for a loan to buy a motorbike to provide her husband with transportation. This couple has four children; one is a construction worker and two are students while the youngest one is 2 years old. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence L. is from the village of District 4. She is 27 years old. Florence is married and has 1 infant child. To make a living, Florence owns & operates a food stall. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of products in her small food stall near the school in their village. Florence has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Florence joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Florence has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Florence is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the third loan taken out by Florence from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Samoeun

texts.en:
Mr. Samoeun P., age 37 (was in the picture) and his wife, Mrs. Sitha Rith, age 31, live in a small village outside of Phnom Penh. They have been married for ten years and have three children: one son and two daughters. All of them are still young.      

Samoeun has been a taxi driver for fifteen years. He drives garment factory workers from his village to the factory and back. Mrs. Sitha Rith sells vegetable in Phnom Penh market. 

Samoeun is asking for his first loan in the amount of $1,000 to purchase a motorbike for his wife to carry vegetable to sell. He also will use a part of the loan to change new wheel of his taxi.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for his wife to transport vegetables to sell plus buy a wheel for his taxi

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria S. is from the village of San Antonio. She is 53 years old. Maria is married and has 2 adult children. To make a living, Maria owns & operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Maria has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Maria joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maria has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Maria is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Maria from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.name: Mrs. Ken Chhoeng Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Ken C. works as a pig breeder at home. Her husband, Mr. Sang Sem, is a farmer who owns a 1 hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to support the family. With this activity, the couple supports three children: two of whom are enrolled in the local public school while the youngest one is 5 years old. Nowadays, they have some problems because it is time to plant, but they do not have enough rice seed and the field has infertile soil. So, to improve production, Mrs. Ken C. is requesting a loan to buy rice seed and fertilizer. 

Eighteen people make up this village bank loan and they are villagers in Rovieng village in Takeo province. Mrs. Ken C. is the village bank president, selected by the other members. They will each use a small piece of the loan for different purposes.

loans.use: To buy rice seed and fertilizer

loans.name: Vath

texts.en:
Mr. Vath K. is 38 years old and is a villager who lives in Treang village in Takeo province. He is a pig middleman and also a pork seller, who earns a small income to support his family. His wife, Mrs. Thim Yun, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice (his wife is in the picture with him). This couple does not have any children. 

To support his business, and in order to increase his income to improve the family's living conditions, Mr. Vath K. decided to ask for a loan to buy 125 kg of pork to sell.

loans.use: To buy 125 kg of pork to sell

loans.name: Son

texts.en:
Mrs. Son S., 29 years old, owns and farms a plot of land next to her house where she grows rice and vegetable crops and for sale when the crops come to maturity. She plants her crops twice a year, and she was taught how to grow mushrooms by her grandparents. She has been married for many years to her husband. The couple has a young child who is enrolled in school. Her husband earns income by selling firewood that he buys from the forest. 

As the farming season is coming, Son S. requests a loan to help her plant rice and vegetable crops.

loans.use: To plant rice and vegetable crops

loans.name: Srey-Em

texts.en:
Mrs. Srey-em S. (in the photo) and her husband, Mr. Sam Sok, have been married since 2005. They have one son and one daughter. Both are still young. They are living about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Srey-em and her husband have been operating a grocery store for more than three years. They buy grocery items from Phnom Penh market for resale in front of their house. Besides selling groceries, they also sell vegetables such as onions, cucumbers, tomatoes, and cabbage. 

The couple hopes to continue expanding their business, so Srey-em is requesting a loan of US$ 1,000 to buy additional grocery items for resale.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items to add to her inventory

loans.name: Phallen

texts.en:
Mrs. Phallen K., 30 years old, and her husband, Mr. Vi Kang, also 30 years old, have been married for two years and have one young daughter. Besides her daughter, she also has her parents living with her. They are living on an island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.  

Phallen has been selling groceries for ten years. She buys grocery items from Oreysey market located in Phnom Penh for resale in front of her house. Her husband is a motor taxi driver. 

Phallen is applying for a loan of US$ 1,000 to purchase more grocery items for resale and she also will use a part of the loan to repair the house where she lives.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery items for resale and repair her house

loans.name: Chann

texts.en:
Mrs. Chann Y. is a 30-year-old married woman who lives in Choes village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice for a living, while her husband, Mr. Try Eng, is a chicken middleman who earns a small income to support the family. Her husband is in the picture with her. Mrs. Chann Y. is the mother of a child, who is the youngest person.

In order to support her husband's business, Mrs. Chann Y. decided to ask for a loan to buy 70 kg of chickens to sell.

loans.use: To buy 70 kg of chickens

loans.name: Mrs. Yaem Sok Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan has fourteen people who are located in Rovieng village, in Takeo province. They will each use a little money from the loan for different purposes to improve their standards of living. Mrs. Yaem S. is a village bank president who has been selected by the other members. She is 64 years old. She owns a general store in the local village where she can resell groceries to support her family. Since her business is going well she wants to expand. So to improve this business, Mrs. Yaem S. is asking for a loan to buy more groceries. Her husband, Mr. Nel Neng, is a farmer who owns one-hectare plot of land, to cultivate rice to sell, to support his family. This couple does not have a child.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida M. is from the village of San Marcos. She is 48 years old. Zenaida is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Zenaida owns & operates a business venture, planting & harvesting a variety of vegetables for sale. Zenaida has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Zenaida joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Zenaida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Zenaida is requesting a new loan of 9000 PHP which will also be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the second loan taken out by Zenaida from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Marilou

Marilou T. is from the town of Fugu Jones. She is 47 years old. Marilou is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Marilou owns & operates a business raising pigs for fattening and sale. Marilou has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 14000 PHP a month for these activities.

loans.name: Nom's Group

Each member will use a small portion of the loan for their individual purposes. Mrs. Nom P. is 52 years old. She and her husband, Mr. Chhun Chhay, are farmers who own two-hectare plot of land where they can grow rice to sell to support their family. Right now they have a problem because their field has infertile soil. So, to improve production, Mrs. Nom P. is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer. The couple supports three children: one is a laborer, one is a construction worker and the other is a student in the local public school.

loans.name: Lerma

texts.en:
Lerma D. is from Barangay Indiana, Bambang, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 34 years old. Lerma is married and has 4 young children. To make a living, Lerma runs a general store, selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Lerma has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 3200 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Lerma joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Lerma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Lerma is requesting a new loan of 13000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Lerma from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering.

loans.name: Somaly's Group

texts.en: This group loan is made up of four people who live in Preaek Cheang Prum village in Kandal province. All the other members have been selected Mrs. Somaly N. as a group leader. She is 36 years old. Her position is a fruit seller at her local market where she earns some money to support her family. Since her business is going well she wants to expand. So to improve this business, Mrs. Somaly N. is applying for a loan to buy more fruit to resell. Her husband, Mr. Phorng Meou, is a policeman earning a low salary to support his family. With these incomes, they support four children, three of whom are attending the local public school, while the youngest one is only two years old.

loans.use: To buy more fruit to resell.

loans.name: Sot

texts.en:
Mr. Sot P. is 26 years old and resides in a rural area of Siem Reap Province. He has a small business in which the main activity is to buy and sell cows, called 'ox-trader'. Sot P. is married with a young child who attends primary school. His wife stays at home to do housework or cultivate rice. 

Mr. Sot P. always leaves home to buy animals and brings them to fatten for a while before selling them to other people. By doing this, he is able to make US$ 5 a day to cover the financial needs of his family. Because the cow trade is very profitable for his family, Sot P. is looking for additional capital to sustain his business growth.

loans.use: To sustain the business growth

loans.name: Mr. Khuoch Huor Village Bank Group

texts.en: Eight people have selected Mr. Khuoch H. as a village bank president. This group is located in Preah Putth village, in Kandal province. All the members will use a small portion of the loan for different purposes, each  to improve their businesses in the future. Mr. Khuoch H. was born in 1984. Now he is a farmer who owns a small piece of land where he can grow rice to sell, to support his family. His wife, Mrs. Chanda Kan, is a pig and chicken breeder at her home. His problem is that his wife’s pigs are too small to sell, but he does not have enough money to support the animals. So, to improve this condition, Mr. Khuoch H. is seeking for a loan to buy pig and chicken food. Through this activity, they support a child who is still too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy pig and chicken food.

loans.name: Chanthy's Group

texts.en: In Preah Putth village, in Kandal province, this group loan consists of four people. They have selected Mrs. Chanthy R. as a group leader. All the members making up this group loan will use a small portion of the loan, each for a different purpose. Mrs. Chanthy R. is a housewife who cooks delicious food for her family. Her husband, Mr. Phorlly Bun, is a construction worker. Her problem is that her yard is lower than neighbors’ yard. So to remedy this problem, Mrs. Chanthy R. is asking for a loan to buy soil to complete her own yard. She is a mother of four children, two of whom are seamstresses in a garment factory, while the others are attending a local public school.

loans.use: To buy soil to complete her own yard.

loans.name: Srey's Group

texts.en: Four people, making up a group loan, are living in Preaek Anhchanh village, in Kandal province. Mrs. Srey M. is a group leader, selected by the other members who will use a small portion of the loan for different purposes. She is a vegetable seller at her local market and she is a farmer who owns a plot of land to grow crops to sell to support her family. Now she has some problems because she does not have enough money to prepare her field for the growing season. So to improve production, Mrs. Srey M. is asking for a loan to buy vegetable seeds, rent a water machine, to buy morning glories to resale. Her husband, Mr. Sambath Neng, is a construction worker. This couple does not have a child.

loans.use: To buy vegetable seeds and rent a water machine.

loans.name: Nann

texts.en:
Mr. Nann N. is 32 years old and resides with other family members in a wooden house located in a rural area of Siem Reap Province. He got married maN. years ago to Naun, age 37, who is a professional teacher in the local public school. The couple is blessed with seven children. 

Mr. Nann N. is a domestic ox-trader. He buys oxen to fatten at his house for a while and he then sells them to other people to raise income. Mr. Nann N. will be using his first loan to purchase a lot of oxen to resell and gain income.

loans.use: To purchase a lot of oxen to resell and gain income

loans.name: Lailanie

texts.en:
Lailanie C. is from the village of Boundary, Sapang Dalaga, Misamis Occidental. She is 40 years old, married, and has one school-aged child. The picture shows Lailanie at her house rather than on her business site.To make a living, Lailanie. owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising pigs for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 8,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2009, Lailanie. joined Kiva partner, GDMPC, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from GDMPC. This loan was used to purchase breeding livestock. Lailanie. is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in future. This loan will be her second from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About GDMPC
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in future

loans.name: Keom Ry's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Keom Ry H. is the group leader who has been selected by four people located in Reang Chuor village, in Kandal province. All of the members are making up a group loan and they will use a small portion of the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Keom Ry H. is 43 years old. Her position is a coffee seller at a local village. Her husband, Mr. Rorn TH., is a farmer who a owns two-hectare plot of land to grow crops to sell to support his family. Her problem is that her husband’s field is far away from an irrigation system and it has infertile soil too. So, to improve production, Mrs. Keom Ry H. is applying for a loan to buy gasoline and fertilizer. She is a mother of three children, one of whom is helping her husband to do farming, while the others are attending a local public school.

loans.use: To buy gasoline and fertilizer.

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en:
Josefina E. is 54 years old and supports three children who are still studying in high school and college. She hopes that, one day, all them will have a degree and enjoy a stable career. This is because she saw from her five elder children how hard it is to support a family and yourself without a stable job and income.
Despite feeling unhappy about her children's situation, Josefina has been able to find strength through Kiva partner, ASHI. With ASHI, she has been able to request a loan and finance her family’s rice farming business, which is managed by her husband and sons. The proceeds from this business go towards meeting her family's needs. However, due to sudden climate change, their business and income is affected. For this reason, Josefina requested a loan to purchase a tricycle (motorcycle with sidecar) for a transportation business to be managed by her husband (while she supports the farming business). Now, Josefina is hoping to purchase another tricycle to be managed by one of her unemployed sons.
Despite the non-stop challenges Josefina encounters in her everyday life as a wife, mother and businesswoman, her hope of having a better kind of life in the future never fades. With ASHI, this hope has become even brighter.

loans.use: To purchase a tricycle (motorcycle with sidecar)

loans.name: Vanney's Group

texts.en:
This group loan consists of four people who are villagers in Boeng Leu village in the Kandal province. Mrs. Vanney M. is the group leader selected by the other members, all of whom will use the loan for different purposes to improve their businesses. She and her husband Mr. Kham Chhean are farmers and own more than a 1-hectare plot of land where they grow crops to sell to support their family. 

Now she has some problems because her field has infertile soil and is far away from an irrigation system. So to improve production, Mrs. Vanney M. is seeking a loan to buy fertilizer and gasoline. 

She is a mother of two children, one of whom is a seamstress in a garment factory, while the other is enrolled in the local public school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and gasoline

loans.name: Samoeun's Group

texts.en: In Boeng Kraom village, in Takeo province, these four people make up a group loan. All of the members have selected Mrs. Samoeun L. as a group leader. She and her husband are farmers who own one point seven-hectare plot of land where they can grow crops to sell, to support their family. Now they have a problem because it is time to plow their field. So to improve production, Mrs. Samoeun L. is requesting for a loan to rent a plowing machine to plow her field. She is a mother of two children, one of whom is helping her to do farming, while the other is attending a local public school.

loans.use: To rent a plowing machine to plow her field.

loans.name: Heing's Group

texts.en: Five people have selected Mrs. Heing K. as a group leader. This goup is located in Ta Reap Doun Sar village in Kandal province. The members of this group loan will each use a small portion of the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Heing K. is a farmer who owns a plot of land where she can earn a little money to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Khom Korng, is a fisherman. Now she has some problems because her husband’s fish net is too old to use. So, to improve this fishing, Mrs. Heing K. is seeking for loan to buy a fishing net and morning glories to grow. She is a mother of two children, one is a construction worker, while the other is a seamstress in a garment factory.

loans.use: To buy a fishing net.

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
Remedios A. is from the village of Misom, Baliangao, Misamis Occidental. She is 59 years old, widowed, and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, Remedios owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector harvesting and selling coconut in the local community. Remedios has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2009, Remedios joined Kiva partner, GDMPC, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. This loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Remedios is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her second from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

About GDMPC
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Socheata's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Socheata S. has been selected by five people who are villagers in Preaek Samraong village, in Kandal province. This group loan is made up of all the members who will each use a small portion of the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Socheata S. was born in 1980. Now she is a cane juice and gasoline seller at her home. She can earn some money from these businesses to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Cham Rung Noun, is a tailor. Although this couple tries to work hard with their businesses, they earn only a little money. So to improve this condition, Mrs. Socheata S. is asking for a loan to buy some cans of gas to resell to start a new business. She is a mother of three children: one is enrolled in the local public school while the youngest two are only five years old and eight months old.

loans.use: To buy some cans of gas to resell.

loans.name: Ihromitdin

texts.ru: Аминов Ихромитдин проживает в городе Турсунзаде. Возраст, 48 лет. Женат, имеет 5 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Ихромитдин занимается торговлей. Имеет торговую точку, где продает масла, мыла и многие другие вещи нужные для хозяйства. Этим видом бизнеса занимается более 17 лет. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота.
texts.en:
Ihromitdin A. lives in the city of Tursun-zoda. He is 48 years old, married and has 5 children. His wife is a homemaker. Ihromitdin is involved in retail sales. He has a retail outlet, where he sells oils, soap and other goods that are necessary for a household. He has been involved in this type of business for over 17 years. He is requesting this loan in order to increase goods turnover.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing goods turnover

loans.name: Edelyn

texts.en:
Edelyn T. is from the village of Misom, Baliangao, Misamis Occidental. She is 29 years old, married, and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Edelyn owns and operates a specialized retail store selling clothing products in the local community. Edelyn has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 2,800 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2009, Edelyn joined Kiva partner, GDMPC, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from GDMPC. This loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Edelyn is requesting a new loan of 3,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her second from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

About GDMPC
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Zohra's Group

texts.en:
Zohra is the wife of M. A. and has no children. She lives with her husband in a two-roomed house, which is situated in the Pakistani city of Borewala, famous for its shrines.
Her husband sells ice blocks in the local community. People come to him to buy ice in the summer season as people like to drink chilled water. He has 15 years' experience in this business. He keeps his ice blocks on his wooden cart.
Zohra is a very kind and patient woman who enjoys doing domestic sewing. She works for customers in her neighborhood and receives a reasonable income. She has received three loans from Asasah, a microfinance institution and Kiva partner, and has successfully repaid them. Now she is applying for a fourth loan in order to expand her husband's business and live a happy life.

loans.use: To purchase more ice blocks to sell

loans.name: Fayziali

texts.ru: Нормамадов Файзиали проживает в городе Турсунзаде. Возраст, 34 года. Женат, имеет 4 детей. Жена занимается растениеводством. Сам Файзиали имеет средне - специальное образование. Работает по профессии. Предоставляет услугу, такси. В этой области более 5 лет. Кредит берет для ремонта автомашины, т.е. он хочет установить оборудование для природного газа и поменять шины.
texts.en:
Fayziali N. lives in the city of Tursun-zoda. He is 34 years old, married and has 4 children. His wife is involved in agriculture. Fayziali has a secondary-specialized education and works in his field. He provides a taxi service. Fayziali has been in this field for over 5 years. He is requesting this loan for car repair, specifically, he wants to install a natural gas conversion kit and change tires.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Car repair

loans.name: Perlita

texts.en:
Perlita P. is from Barangay Santo Domingo, Bambang, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 61 years old. Perlita is married and has 5 adult children. To make a living, Perlita owns & operates a tailoring business, providing general alteration & tailoring services to local community members. Perlita has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Perlita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Perlita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional fabrics & materials. Perlita is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional tailoring equipment such as needles & threads. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Perlita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional tailoring equipment such as needles & threads.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita T. is from the village of Parabba, Peñablanca, Cagayan. She is 36 years old. Teresita is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Teresita owns & operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Teresita has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 3500 PHP a month for these activities.

Teresita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Teresita has successfully repaid a previous loan  from ASKI. Teresita is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the eighth loan taken out by Teresita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Samina's Group

texts.en:
Samina lives with her family in a three room house in Borewala, a city of shrines in Pakistan. She has four children, three sons and one daughter. Her eldest son works in a rice mill and the other three are studying. Her daughter reads in 11th standard, while one son is in 9th standard and the youngest is in 2nd standard. A hardworking housewife who loves taking care of her family, Samina arises early in the morning and sends her children to school, and when they come back she provides them fresh cooked food.

For five years her husband, M. S., has been operating a grocery shop in the market and generates income for the family. Samina, who has taken three loans from Asasah and successfully repaid them, is now applying for a new loan so she can expand her husbands business by buying the required items for his grocery shop.

loans.use: Purchase groceries for grocery shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase the seeds of potatoes and onions

loans.name: Conchita

texts.en:
Conchita P. is from the village of San Marcos. She is 59 years old. Conchita is married. To make a living, Conchita grows crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting  a variety of vegetables for sale. Conchita has been engaged in her business for more than two years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Conchita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Conchita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Conchita is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the ninth loan taken out by Conchita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishers, and small-business entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers

loans.name: Mtama Kulanga Group

texts.en:
Tatu M. M., age 39, is married with two children, who are ages 15 and 11. She has run a kiosk business selling juice, water, sodas, rice, sugar and beans since 2008. She works from 7 a.m. to 9 p.m. daily and she is able to make a monthly profit of about $208.

This will be Tatu’s first Motisha loan. This is a loan product from Tujijenge Tanzania (a Kiva partner) that allows clients in good standing to access a loan before they have completed their existing loan. It serves as "top-up" financing. Tatu wants this Motisha loan in order to increase her stock. She will increase the things which are out of stock. Her dreams are to expand her business by getting a bigger frame and to take her children to good schools.

Tatu will share this loan with her loan group Mtama Kulanga, which totals six members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back the loan. 

In the picture, Tatu is the first on the right.

loans.use: To buy products that are out of stock

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en: Teresita A. is from the village of Aurora, Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 52 years old. Teresita is married and has an adult child. To make a living, Teresita owns and operates a manufacturing business. The main source of income for the business comes from manufacturing and selling products like "tinagaktak" (a crispy, rice-based dessert) to local businesses and community members. Teresita has been engaged in her business for more than two years and earns approximately 8,000 Philippine pesos a month from it. In 2010, Teresita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresita is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products. This will be the first loan taken out by Teresita from GDMPC, a Kiva partner. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products

loans.name: Ivy

texts.en: Ivy B. is from the village of San Juan, Aurora, Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 31 years old. Ivy is married and has six school-aged children. To make a living, Ivy raises crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting a variety of vegetables for sale, like eggplant, okra, string beans, etc. Ivy has been engaged in her business for over 12 years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2008, Ivy joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ivy has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC, a Kiva partner. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers, such as manure. Ivy is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the sixth loan taken out by Ivy from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

location.town: San Juan, Aurora Zamboanga Del Sur

loans.name: Oscar

texts.en:
Oscar U. is from the village of La Victoria, Aurora, Zamboanga Del Sur. He is 45 years old and married with four school-aged children. To make a living, Oscar raises corn for sale. He has been engaged in this business for over 6 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Oscar joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6000 PHP from GDMPC which was used to to purchase additional seeds, seedlings to raise. Oscar is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the third loan taken out by Oscar from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

location.town: La Victoria, Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur

loans.name: Mohammad Hanef

texts.en: M. Hanef is the son of M. R.. He lives in district of 8, Kabul, Afghanistan. He is married with three children who are in school. He wants to take a loan for his fruit and vegetable shop. He would like to expand his business and buy more items for his shop that he does not stock but are in high demand in the market. He would like to say that Kiva is an effective process.

loans.use: to expand his business

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Yolanda C. is from the village of Taguitic,  Kapatagan, Lanao Del Norte. She is 35 years old and married with five school-aged children. To make a living, Yolanda has a retail store selling daily use products such as milk, milo, eggs, vinegar, cooking oil, biscuits, shampoo, soap and toothpaste. She has been engaged in her business for over 22 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Yolanda joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Yolanda is requesting a loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Yolanda from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family. 

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. loans.name: Kaniza's Group

texts.en: Kaniza is the wife of A. A.. They live in a three-room house with their four children in Borewala, city of shrines, in Pakistan. Both husband and wife are very hardworking. They operate their own businesses and their children stay at home with their grandparents. Kaniza has an animal sales business. She buys young animals, grows them, and sells them at a profit. Her husband is involved in selling clothes, He buys clothes from Faisalabad (which is famous for its textile industry) and sells them in different markets of the city. Kaniza is applying for a loan from Asasah to invest in her husband’s business because he wants to vary his stock with high-quality fabrics which can make him more money.

Jocelyn C. is from the village of Migpange Bonifacio. She is 38 years old. Jocelyn is the group leader of a 4-member group loan offered by GDMPC. Jocelyn is married and has two school-aged children. Jocelyn owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as cooking oil, eggs, rice, sugar, shampoo, soap, & toothpaste in the local community. Jocelyn has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 6,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it.

Jocelyn joined GDMPC this year to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Jocelyn from GDMPC. loans.name: Kev

texts.en: Kev P., 42, lives in a wooden house with her children; three of them are students and the fourth is employed raising pigs. Kev P. earns her living by selling vegetables at the local market. She travels to buy vegetables from a farm a long way from her house. She has done this for years while her husband works with her on the business side. To make her vegetable business more successful, Kev P. is taking out a loan to use as additional capital.

loans.use: To use as additional capital.

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en:
Sixty-three-year-old Josefina D. is one of the oldest members in one of the ASHI centers. As a member for 10 years, she has able to establish good rapport with her co-members and has proved herself worthy of a loan. She runs a small variety store financed with the loans and has able to make profits which she use to support her family and to make payments to ASHI on time. Josefina’s children already have their own families but she and her husband never felt alone because her business keeps them busy every day, and one of her grandchildren lives with them. They are paying this grandson's college fees.

Josefina’s requested loan will be used to sustain her business and increase her profits so she can continue to support her grandson’s education until he graduates from college and ready to have his own career. For herself and her husband, she is hoping that one day they will enjoy the fruits of their hard work by seeing their business stable and established.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and working capital

texts.en: Mr. Sophat B., 38, lives in Banteay village in Takeo province. Apart from farming, which is his main activity, Sophat also owns a small electronics shop where he sells VCDs, DVDs, VCD players, televisions etc. The secondary business earns Sophat a small revenue to support his family. For his electronics shop, Mr. Sophat B. is requesting a loan to purchase more televisions, DVDs, VCDs and VCD players to expand his business activities. With this loan, he hopes to increase his income and improve the lifestyle of his family. His wife, Mrs. Mom May, is a green grass seller. The couple has three children who are students in the local school and also support their parents' businesses. His wife is in the picture with him.

Her husband, Mr. Ron Yi, is a horse cart driver who supports the family through his small income. In order to make her transportation easier, Mrs. Phai Y. decided to ask for a loan to purchase a motorcycle. This couple has a child who is just two years old.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle

loans.name: Toch's Group

texts.en:
This group loan has five people located in Boeng Kandal village in Kandal province. All the members will use a small piece of the loan for different purposes to improve their businesses in the future. They have selected Mrs. Toch P. as their group leader. 

Mrs. Toch P. was born in 1957. She is a mother of two children, one of whom is a dessert seller, while the other is a government worker. She and her husband, Mr. Pou Heng, are farmers who own a .09 hectare plot of land to grow crops to sell to support their family. 

Now they have a problem because their field is far from an irrigation system. So to improve production, Mrs. Toch P. is asking for a loan to buy a water machine.

loans.use: To buy a water machine.

loans.name: Mith

texts.en:
Mrs. Mith S. is 31 years old and lives in Klaong Tvear village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. 

Aside from farming, she is also grocery seller. Her husband, Mr. Mao Yin, is a photographer in the local village. Her husband is in the picture with her. With these businesses, they earn a small income to support their family. This couple has a child who is a seamstress in a garment factory. 

To make transportation easier, Mrs. Mith S. decided to ask for a loan to buy a motorbike.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Meas

texts.en: Mrs. Meas N., 46, sells vegetables at the local busy market. She earns about $1 a day and takes care of three children, while the remaining three are married and live away from home. Two of her daughters are employed at the garment factory. Her husband, Mr. Nouv Hal, fishes in the river and earns about $3.50 a day. There are many grasshoppers born in this season which is a popular snack food. Meas N. needs tools to catch the grasshoppers to sell, which will add to her income. This is why she has requested a loan from Kiva for $200.

loans.use: To buy tools to catch grasshoppers.

loans.use: to enlarge his shop

loans.name: Meoun

texts.en:
Mrs. Meoun S. is a 29-year old married woman who lives in in Klaong Tvear village in Takeo province. She is a pig breeder at home and earns a small income to support her family living. 

Her husband, Mr. Nou Choy, is a chicken middleman who earns a small revenue to add to his wife’s income to improve the family living. This couple has three children; two attend the local school. The youngest one is 4 years old. Her husband is in the picture with her.

In order to increase her income to improve the family living, Mrs. Meoun S. decided to ask for a loan to buy six more piglets and pig food for pig breeding.

loans.use: To buy more six piglets and pig food.

loans.name: Sokhorn's Group

texts.en: Four people made up a group loan located in Boeng Kandal village in Kandal province. Mrs. Sokhorn S. is the group leader, selected by the other members who will each use a small piece of the loan for a different purpose. She is a farmer who owns a 1.2-hectare plot of land to grow crops to sell to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Kheang Peng, is a fisherman. Now she has a problem because her husband’s fishing boat is broken. So to improve this condition, Mrs. Sokhorn S. is applying for a loan to fix the fishing boat. She is a mother of four children. One of her children helps her to do farming and the others are studying in the local public school. The day of the loan disbursement Mrs. Sokhorn S. was busy working in the field. Instead, her husband, Mr. Kheang Peng, received the loan for her. The photo above is of Mrs. Sokhorn S.'s husband.

loans.use: To fix a fishing boat

In order to support her farming, Mrs. Soy Chann decided to ask for a loan to buy two oxen to support her farming crop. This couple has three children. loans.name: Soyolmaa

texts.en: Soyolmaa D. is a 47-year-old woman who lives with her husband and daughter in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. In 2005, she started her own small business selling flour at the local food market. She buys flour from wholesalers and resells it at retail to local residents. As her business grew, she increased her inventory to include rice and sugar as well. Soyolmaa's husband transports her flour, rice and sugar from the wholesale market. To increase the household’s income, her husband also runs a car transport service for other wholesalers. Soyolmaa's daughter Oyuntugs just graduated from high-school. Since she founded her business, her living conditions have improved. Now she had owns house with a yard and a car. Soyolmaa is requesting a loan to purchase more sugar and noodles to increase her inventory. She is a humble, shy and hard-working person. She says, "I have a dream to have my own grocery store one day to ensure my only daughter's future life."

loans.use: to purchase more sugar and noodles to increase her inventory

loans.name: Sorn

texts.en: Mrs. Sorn P. is 50 years old and is a villager who lives in Krouch village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Dos Nheb, are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate rice for a living. For this farm, Mrs. Sorn P. decided to ask for a loan to pay out for a laborer to plow her farm. Aside from farming, Mr. Dos Nheb is also a bike repairer in the local village who earns a small income to support his family. This couple has four children. One of the children is a seamstress in a garment factory, one is a construction worker and the other two are students in the local school. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To hire laborers to plow her farm.

loans.name: Korb

texts.en: Mrs. Korb H. is 35 years old and is a villager who lives in Thma Sa village in Takeo province. She is a broom maker who earns a small income to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Ny Sam, is a construction worker who can support and improve his family living through his small salary. In order to support her husband's work place, Mrs. Korb H. decided to ask for a loan to purchase a motorcycle to support her husband's transportation. This couple has four children. Three of the children are attending the local school while the youngest one is four years old. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle

loans.name: Maribel

texts.en:
Maribel E. is from the village of Brgy. Sto. Domingo, Bambang, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 38 years old. Maribel is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Maribel owns & operates a business raising pigs for fattening and sale. Maribel has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP when she sells her raised animal.

In 2009, Maribel joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maribel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future. Maribel is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Maribel from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase feed & other supplies

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to repair his house

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy sheet metal with which to make buckets

loans.name: Mrs. Sokhom Chea Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan consists of 17 people wH. are villagers I. Ta Reap Doun Sar village I. Kandal province. Mrs. Sokhom C. is the village president, selected by the other members wH. will each use a small piece of the loan for a different purpose. She was born I. 1968 and her position is a vegetable seller at her local market. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it. So to improve this business, Mrs. Sokhom C. is requesting a loan to buy more vegetables for resale. Her husband, Mr. Davy On, is a construction worker. She is a mother of three children all attending the local public school.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables for resale

loans.name: Creak

texts.en: Mrs. Creak M. is a 30-year-old married woman and a villager who lives in Prey Sbat village in Takeo province. She is farmer who owns 1.50 hectares of land to cultivate rice for a living. In order to support this farm, Mrs. Creak M. decided to ask for a loan to buy two oxen to support her farm crop. Her husband, Mr. Sok Sam, is a construction worker who can support his family with his small salary. This couple has three children. Two of the children are attending the local school and the youngest one is two years old.

loans.use: To buy two oxen

loans.name: Oin

texts.en: Mrs. Oin Y. is a 30-year-old married woman and a villager who lives in Ta Suon village, Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Kosal Kril, is a cow middleman who earns a small profit to support and improve his family's living conditions. For this cow business, Mrs. Oin Y. decided to ask for a loan to buy three cows to support her husband's business. This couple has two children who are both too young to study or work.

loans.use: To buy three cows

loans.name: Mrs. Vanna San Village Bank Group

texts.en: In Ta Reab DoU. Sar village in Kandal province, there is a village bank loan, which consists of 17 people. Mrs. Vanna S. is the village bank president selected by the members. Each of the members will use a small piece of the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Vanna S. is 46 years old and her position is a vegetable seller at her local market. Now she is a widow with five children. Two of the children are seamstresses in the garment factory, one is a construction worker, one is a fisherman, and one attends the local public school. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand. So to improve this business, Mrs. Vanna S. is applying for a loan to buy more vegetables to sell. The rest of the loan she will use to fix a fishing boat.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to sell

loans.name: Teodorico

texts.en:
Teodorico G. is from the village of Del Corpuz, Cabatuan, Isabela. He is 56 years old. Teodorico is married and has six adult children. To make a living, Teodorico owns & operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. Teodorico has been engaged in his business for over 30 years and earns approximately 50,000 PHP every cropping.

In 2009, Teodorico joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teodorico is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Teodorico from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise

loans.name: Seang Hai

texts.en: Mrs. Seang Hai S. is 36 years old and lives in Bang Bat village, Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. For this farm, Mrs. Seang Hai S. decided to ask for loan to buy a water machine, pesticide and fertilizer to support her farming crop. Her husband, Mr. Cheng Pann, is a construction worker. He receives a small salary to support his family. This couple has two children. One of the children is attending the local school and one is just two years old. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy a water machine, pesticide and fertilizer and pesticide

loans.name: Khlok

texts.en: Mrs. Khlok P. is 32 years old and lives in Angk Svay Chek village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Sam Oeun Dy, are farmers who own two hectares of land to cultivate rice for a living. For this farm, Mrs. Khlok P. decided to ask for a loan to pay a laborer to plow her farm and to buy fertilizer and pesticide to support her farming crop. Aside from farming, Mrs. Khlok P. is a silk weaver at home. She earns a small income from this business to support her family. This couple has four children. One of the children is a laborer and the other three are students in the local school. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To hire a laborer to plow her farm and to buy fertilizer and pesticide

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Sophal

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophal V. is 45 years old and a villager from Ampil Lech village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate vegetables and rice. Mrs. Sophal V. has decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer, pesticide and garlic seed to support her farm.
In addition to farming, Mrs. Sophal V. works from home as a silk weaver. Her husband (pictured with her) is a teacher in the local school, for which he receives a small salary to add to his wife's income to improve their standard of living. The couple has six children – two are silk weavers, two are silk weaving laborers, while the other two are students.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticide and garlic seed

loans.name: Kheg

texts.en: In the photo is Mr. Kheg H., a hard-working 39-year-old man. To pursue a daily income, Kheg H. leaves his home in order to buy a few cows from a rural farmer. Then he fattens the cows for a while at his home before selling them to gain income. He has a life partner in his wife who stays at home to raise pigs and crops. They are good parents to six teenage kids, all of whom are students in the local public school. Kheg H. is running his business smoothly and gaining much income. Because Kheg H. has little money, he can only buy a few cows. So he would like to increase his business capital by asking for a loan from Kiva for $600, which he will use to purchase more cows to resell.

loans.use: To purchase more cows to resell.

loans.name: Mr. Nis Mang Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan is made up of 22 villagers from Ta Reap Doun Sar village in Kandal province. Mr. Nis M. is the village bank president, who has been selected by the other members. The members will all use their loans for different purposes.
Mr. Nis M. is a fisherman. His wife, Mrs. Vannara Yoeurn, is a fish seller at her local market. Presently, Mr. Nis M. has some problems because his fishing net and fishing boat are broken. To improve this situation, Mr. Nis M. is applying for a loan to buy a new fishing net and fix his fishing boat. He is a father of four children, two of whom attend the local public school, while the others are too small to work or study.
On the day of the loan disbursement, Mr. Nis M. was busy working. His wife, Mrs. Vannara Yoeurn, received the loan for him, and the photo above shows Mr. Nis M.'s wife.

loans.use: To buy a new fishing net and fix his fishing boat

loans.name: Sareth

texts.en:
Mrs. Sareth H. is 38 years old and is a villager who lives in Sman Muni village in Takeo province. She is a grocery seller and also a silk weaver at home.  Her husband, Mr. Reth Vong, is a farmer who owns 1.20-hectare of land to cultivate rice. With these businesses, they can earn a small income to support their family. 

In order to increase income to improve the family's standard of living, Mrs. Sareth H. decided to ask for a loan to buy piglets and pig food for pig breeding. With the rest of the loan she wants to buy fertilizer to support her husband's farming. This couple has three children: two are students in the local school while the youngest one is 3 years old. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy piglets and pig food

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Yut

texts.en: Mrs. S., 30 years old, is a crop grower from the Siem Reap Province. She runs her business on her own farmland where she grows different kinds of vegetables like cabbage, rice, and morning glories. In additional to her farming business, S. built a small store in front of her home where she sells snack food and cooking ingredients. She currently earns an average of $3 a day. S. is married with a young school-aged child, while her husband earns money by distilling wine and raising pigs. S. will be using her first loan to accrue inventory for her store, as well as to buy more piglets to raise.

loans.use: To accrue inventory and buy piglets

loans.name: Aida

texts.en:
Aida L. is from the town of Surallah. She is 46 years old. Aida is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Aida owns & operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. 

Aida joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Aida has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Aida is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Aida from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future

loans.name: Yut

texts.en: Yut H., a 39-year-old married mother caring for four school-aged children, is a domestic cultivator who raises pigs and crops. Another source of family income is her husband, who fishes around the river. The coming rainfall season is a possible condition for farming; Yut H. is lacking some supplies to use on her field. Because she doesn’t have money, Yut H. is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer and crop seeds to grow.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seeds

loans.name: Teresa

texts.en: Teresa B. is 50 years of age and is a very simple woman. Her ambition in life is to see her three children settled and happy with whatever life and career they have chosen. Now, all of them still live with her yet they have their own sources of income. It may be small but at least they have something to spend for themselves without asking her for much, unlike before. Despite being a mother at home, Teresa always makes sure that her family has something for a meal and re-enforces the needs of her children, which they can no longer afford. Because of that, Teresa can’t save to increase their capital investment in their baluster making business in order for it to grow and increase production. For her, the needs of her family must come first, yet she is still hoping that through the increasing amount of loan she can request from ASHI, business plans will come true. Someday, when her children are settled, she hopes to accept a huge volume of orders for their product and be known for the fine and good quality of balusters made and managed by her husband. She also hopes to employ more people to work with them for a more efficient production.  Once she has more profit, she plans to renovate their house.

loans.use: To purchase materials for baluster manufacturing business.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase materials needed to provide her services

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Bella

texts.en:
Thirty-three-year-old Bella S., from the town of Sto. Niño, is married and has four school-aged children. For the past five years Bella has been raising pigs for fattening and sale in order to make a living.

In 2005, Bella joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan from CEVI, Bella is requesting a new loan, her ninth, of 15000 PHP to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children and improve the living conditions of her family.

About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also savings, insurance, and training through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Sokhorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokhorn O. is 48 years old and lives in Kdei Ta Hok village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Hul Chheal, are farmers who own 1.80-hectare of land to cultivate rice. Besides farming, Mrs. Sokhorn O. is also a pig breeder who can earn a small income to help support the family. 

To support both businesses, Mrs. Sokhorn O. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer, pesticide and gasoline to improve the rice crop and to buy pig food. This couple has a child who is a student in the local school. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticide, gasoline and pig food

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase additional second-hand goods to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase livestock feed

loans.name: Zhiparkul's Group

texts.en:
Zhiparkul N. is the leader of the group, 47. Her husband makes money providing car repair services, and they have a 15-year-old son attending school.
