While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Diên Lộc Nhóm 01 (Nhóm 01). D. is married and has three adult children. She owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling scrap metal and other used-products in the local community. D. has been engaged in this business for over three years and earns approximateL. 3,500,000 VND a month. D. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. H. đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 5.152.000 VND từ SEDA. Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua thức ăn gia súc & các loại cung cấp khác. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 7.392.000 VND. Khoản vay sẽ là 2nd khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA. Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm: 1. Nguyễn Thị D. (0) là 47 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 7.392.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực sản xuất. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh chế tạo hàng nội thất. 2. Nguyễn Thị D. (0) là 29 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 7.392.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là cung cấp dịch vụ tái chế. 3. Nguyễn Thị M. (0) là 60 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 7.392.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc. 4. Nguyễn Thị T. (0) là 47 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc. Về SEDA: Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam *Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Ma. Bella

texts.en:
Ma. Bella P., 38 years old,  is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Ma. Bella owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Ma. Bella has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3500 PHP a month for these activities.

Ma. Bella joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ma. Bella has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Ma. Bella is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the second loan taken out by Ma. Bella from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Anahit

texts.en: Anahit H. is 54 years old. She lives alone, because her husband lives in Russia, and her children are married and live separately from their mother. For about 10 years, Anahit has been engaged in selling glassware in a shop which is located on one of Vanadzor's central streets. She sells kitchen utensils, tea things, vases, etc. Anahit purchases an assortment of products from Yerevan once or twice a month. Anahit needs a 300.000 AMD loan to buy dinner and tea services, and sets of forks and knives for her shop.

loans.use: To buy dinner and tea services, and sets of forks and knives for her shop

loans.name: Melindy

texts.en:
47-year-old Melindy C. is from the town of Surallah. She is married and has three children. To make a living, Melindy owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting & harvesting  a variety of vegetables for sale. She also grows hogs in her backyard. Melindy has been engaged in her business for over 10 years now.

In 2008, Melindy joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Melindy has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Melindy is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure and hog feed. This will be the sixth loan taken out by Melindy from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure and hog feed

loans.name: Albert

texts.en:
Albert A. is 44 years old and he lives in Vanadzor city with his wife and two sons: one of them is an elementary school pupil, and another is a student. For about 20 years Albert has been managing his butcher shop, which he runs in a rented space at Vanadzor central food market. With profit from his business, Albert supports his family and pays for his elder son’s education. 

Albert needs a 900.000 AMD loan to buy a car to move meat from villagers to his butcher shop, which will reduce his business costs.

loans.use: To buy a car to move meat from villagers to his butcher shop

loans.name: Merly

texts.en:
Merly M., 43 years old, is from the town of Surallah. She is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Merly owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Merly has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

Merly joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Merly has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Merly is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure and other farm supplies. This will be the sixth loan taken out by Merly from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children and improve the living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure and other farm supplies

loans.name: Lilymar

texts.en:
Lilymar S. is a model member of ASHI and one of the most reliable. She was very poor when she joined the institution; however, having a wealth of dreams, she eventually climbed out of poverty a little bit. Loans she received from ASHI were used wisely, to finance a business she could manage and enjoy. As the years have gone by and the loan amounts she is qualified to receive have grown larger, the variety and volume of inventory in Lilymar’s small “sari-sari” store has also increased. Now, her store is not just a typical sari-sari, which means a shop with a few selected grocery items, including some foodstuff and beverages, but it’s a bit of a mini grocery store that has a larger volume of various kinds of products.

Sustaining a business--especially for a woman who had not undergone any informal training on managing a business and cash flow--is very challenging. For Lilymar, the inspiration of graduating her three children from college and supporting their needs until they can manage their own lives encourages her to become more productive. Her bitter childhood experiences, living a very poor kind of life until she had her own family, drive her inner self to aim for more business. This way, she can make her children’s lives much better.

Aside from her sari-sari store business, Lilymar used some of the loans she received from ASHI to purchase tricycles (motorcycles with sidecar), one for a transportation business to be managed by her husband, and the other one for hire. Because Lilymar realized that the income from this business is higher and more stable than that from her store, she and her husband decided to purchase another one, which will also be for hire.

loans.use: To purchase an additional tricycle (motorcycle with sidecar) for a transportation business

loans.name: Marlon

texts.en: Marlon D. is from the village of San Jose. He is 35 years old, is married, and has four infant children. Marlon owns and operates a business raising pigs for breeding. He has been engaged in his business for over twelve years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2006, Marlon joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase pig feed and other supplies. Marlon is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase pig feed and other supplies. This loan will be his twelfth from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay his children’s tuition fees. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase pig feed and other supplies

loans.name: Nida

texts.en:
Nida E., from the town of Surallah, is 33 years old, married, and has a three-year-old child. To make a living, Nida has been planting and harvesting fruits and vegetables for sale for over 3 years, earning approximately 3500 PHP a month.,

In 2008, Nida joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan from CEVI, she is now requesting a new one, her fifth, of 15000 PHP to purchase fertilizers and hogs to raise. Nida plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.name: Elmira's Group

texts.en: Elmira N. is the leader of this group. She is 23. Two years ago, with an initial investment of 10,000 soms (approximately 217 USD) she rented a store and began to sell convenience goods. In this way she earns 3,500 soms (approximately 76 USD) per month. To earn additional income, Elmira’s husband works in construction. With the money received from this loan, Elmira plans to purchase various goods in order to increase the turnover of her business. In the future she wants to expand her business and build a new house. Klara K. is 28. She works as an operator at a gas station and her husband is a bus driver. A year ago, with an initial investment of 1,000 USD, Klara opened a kiosk where she sells convenience goods. In this way she makes 13,000 soms (approximately 282 USD) per month. She and her husband also breed cattle to earn more income. Now, Klara wants to obtain a loan to purchase a calf for breeding and also various goods to increase the turnover of her business. Nazgul T. is the treasurer of the group. She is 35, is married, and her husband works as a builder. Five years ago, with an initial investment of 10,000 soms (approximately 217 USD), Nazgul bought a cow and started to breed cattle. She also sells milk to make money and, in this way, she makes 3,400 soms (approximately 74 USD) per month. She has three daughters and a son, all of whom study at school. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase sheep to increase the number of her livestock. In the future, she plans to purchase a container and a vehicle. Erlan I. is 25 and is married. He works as a security guard in a factory and his monthly salary is 6,000 soms (approximately 130 USD). He has a two-year-old daughter so his wife stays at home to take care of her. In order to make money Erlan also breeds cattle, sometimes selling some after fattening. In the future he plans to repair his house and purchase a vehicle. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.name: Tessie

Tessie C. is from the town of Surallah. She is 46 years old, is married, and has six school-aged children.

loans.name: Merilyn

texts.en:
Merilyn M. is from the village of Butuay, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 52 years old, is married, and has two adult children. Merilyn owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling clothing, shoes and school products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over twenty-five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Merilyn joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for her business. Merilyn is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her fifth from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Almoudou

texts.fr:
Âgé de 45 ans, Monsieur Almoudou T. est marié et père de 4 filles. Il réside avec sa famille à Médine, un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas eu la chance d’avancer à l’école, il s’est très vite initié depuis plus de trente années à la couture, auprès de son oncle à Sikasso. Son atelier se situe au grand marché de Sikasso et la plupart de sa clientèle est composée des hommes surtout les forains. Avec une telle expérience dans le domaine, il jouit d’une parfaite confiance de la famille des tailleurs ce qui lui a valu la présidence du Comité de Surveillance de l’Association des Tailleurs de Sikasso (A.T.S.). En plus de la couture, il achète des machines à coudre à Lomé (république de Togo) et des tissus pour  homme afin de les revendre aux tailleurs de Sikasso. 
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire des commandes de plus en plus croissantes, il sollicite ce deuxième prêt auprès de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est en partenariat il y environ deux ans. 
Ce deuxième prêt lui permettra d’acheter, 15 machines à coudre et 10 complets tissus.
Avec ce prêt, il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 250 000 FCFA. Avec ces bénéfices réalisés, il compte résoudre l’essentielle de ses dépenses personnelles, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son atelier.
texts.en:
Mr. Almoudou T., aged 45, is married and the father of four girls.  He resides with his family in Médine, one of the working-class districts of Sikasso City (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  Not having had the chance to advance in school, he quickly got introduced to tailoring from his uncle in Sikasso over thirty years ago.  His workshop is located at the big market of Sikasso, and most of his customers are men, particularly market vendors.  With such experience in this domain, he enjoys the complete confidence of the family of tailors which has earned him the presidency of the Comité de Surveillance de l’Association des Tailleurs de Sikasso (A.T.S.), the supervisory committee of the association of tailors of Sikasso.  In addition to being a clothier, he buys sewing machines in Lomé (Republic of Togo) and men's fabrics in order to resell them to Sikasso tailors.  Concerned about doing better in meeting his continuously increasing orders, he is requesting this second loan from the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso with which he has had a partnership for about two years.  This second loan will enable him to buy fifteen sewing machines and ten sets of fabric.  With this loan, he envisions making a monthly profit of 250,000 francs CFA.  With the profits earned, he plans on resolving important personal expenses of his, to help cover family expenses, to pay the loan interest, and to invest the rest in his workshop.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying various items

loans.name: Lilia

texts.en:
Through her membership in ASHI, 57-year-old Lilia P. has been able to develop self-confidence in dealing with other people. Her sweet and bitter experiences with her co-members in the ASHI center she belongs to, strengthens her determination and has made her tough enough to go on with her mission for herself and her family.

Lilia is one of the poorest mothers in her community. She is a widow and the sole provider of her two children whose ages now are 21 and 25. Despite her family incurring too many expenses in excess of the income she makes from her sari-sari (variety) store business, which is financed by the loans she receives from ASHI, Lilia is always hopeful that she will be able to keep her business, even if it is not yet growing.

With ASHI and the larger amount of loan she can request, in time Lilia will be able to grow her business and make it more stable and profitable. By then, along with her children, she will be able to realize her vision of living a better kind of life. For now, all of them are helping each other and supporting each other’s needs.

Lilia’s eldest child has a sporadic and small income being a small-time fisherman; her youngest is a hired driver.

loans.use: To purchase additional grocery items and beverages for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Dialia

texts.fr:
Née le 17 Janvier 1976 à Sikasso ville, Dialia B. est divorcée et mère d’une petite fille. Elle réside avec sa fille chez son grand frère à Sanoubougou I, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso.
Après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans réussite, elle décida de mener les activités d’achat et de vente d’habillements  il y a environ quinze ans, depuis très jeune, auprès de sa grande sœur. 
L’insuffisance des ressources financières pour bien mener cette activité constitue l’objet et la justification de cette demande de prêt à Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle elle est en partenariat depuis le 18 janvier 2006. Il a bénéficié un premier prêt qui a été correctement remboursé. 
Ainsi après une pose d’un an, elle sollicite un deuxième prêt qui lui permettra d’acheter, des habits  pour enfants, 40 complets, 20 couvertures, 6 douzaines de poudre et 5 douzaines de parfums à Cotonou et à Lomé (Républiques du Bénin et de Togo en Afrique de l’Ouest). Elle revend ses marchandises au comptant dans sa boutique située sur la route de Bobo Dioulasso (république de Burkina Faso) à une clientèle composée essentiellement des femmes.
Avec ce prêt, elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 150 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour résoudre l’essentielle de ses dépenses, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Dialia B. was born on January 17, 1976 in Sikasso. She is divorced and the mother of one daughter. She lives with her daughter at her older brother’s home in Sanoubougou I, one of the working neighborhoods in the town of Sikasso. After several unsuccessful attempts, she decided, at a young age, about 15 years ago, to take up the purchase and sell of clothing alongside her older sister. The lack of financial resources to conduct her business properly is the reason and cause behind her request for a loan from Soro Yiriwaso. She has been a member since January 18, 2006. She has received one previous loan, which has been fully reimbursed. After a one year hiatus, she is requesting a second loan that will allow her to buy children’s clothing, 40 suits, 20 blankets, 6 dozen of powder and 5 dozens of perfumes from Cotonou and Lomé (Republic of Benin and Togo, West Africa). She retails her merchandises for cash in her shop located on the Bobo Dioulasso road (Republic of Burkina Faso). Her customer base is mostly women. She is planning on making a monthly profit of 150 000 Francs CFA which will be used to provide for the bulk of her expenses, take part in covering household expenses, pay back her loan and invest the rest in her activity.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothing and various other goods.

loans.name: Drissa

texts.fr:
Monsieur Drissa B. est un célibataire de 25 ans qui vit dans une famille élargie à Hamdallaye “Zantiguibougou”, un des quartiers périphériques de ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur  B. après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans succès, s’est initié  il y a environ trois ans au commerce notamment la vente d’articles divers (huile alimentaire, sel de cuisine, spaghetti, savons etc.) dont il dispose une place au niveau du marché avec une clientèle composée essentiellement des femmes de ménages. Il est beaucoup sollicité de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso  avec qui, il est à son deuxième prêt individuel. Le prêt précédent a été correctement remboursé.
 Avec ce deuxième prêt, il compte acheter 4 futs d’huile alimentaire, 15 paquets de maggi, 5 sacs de sel, 2 cartons de spaghetti, 2 cartons de savon, 1 carton de sardines , etc. 
Il s’approvisionne auprès de commerçants grossistes de la place avant de les revendre en détail, au  comptant et à crédit.
Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 190 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Mr. Drissa B. is a 25-year old single man who lives in an extended family in Hamdallaye "Zantiguibougou", one of the peripheral districts of the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Having had several unsuccessful activities, Mr. B. started a business three years ago selling various products (edible oil, kitchen salt, spaghetti, soaps, etc.); he has a place in the market where he sells to a customer base made up essentially of housewives. He is in great demand from his customers owing to the quality of his products. In order to satisfy his ever increasing customer base, he decided to join the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, with whom he is on his second individual loan. The previous loan was repaid on time. With this second loan, he is planning on buying four barrels of edible oil, 15 packets of "Maggi" stock cubes, five bags of salt, two cartons of spaghetti, two cartons of soaps, one carton of sardines, etc. He gets his supplies from local wholesalers before selling them retail for cash and on credit. With this loan he is planning on making a monthly profit of 190,000FCFA, which will be used essentially to expand his business, to contribute to the household expenses and to pay off the interest on his loan.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase diverse products

loans.name: Kaniba

texts.fr:
Monsieur  Kaniba F. est un polygame de plus de 50 ans, père de seize enfants qui réside avec sa famille à Sanoubougou, le centre ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur F. est chauffeur de formation, après vingt années d’exercices de cette profession en république de Côte d’Ivoire, finit par s’initier depuis son retour au bercail il y a environ six ans, au petit commerce notamment  à l’achat et à la vente de Cigarettes, bonbons, allumettes, Chewing-gum laits en poudre, Thés, sucres, savons, et maintenant au transfert de crédits téléphoniques, à la charge des batteries et  à la vente des cartes téléphoniques. Il est d’ailleurs le représentant de la société Nationale de Tabacs et Allumettes du Mali (SONATAM SA) au niveau de son quartier. Il est beaucoup sollicité de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida, il y a trois ans,  de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son troisième prêt individuel. Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
 Il compte acheter avec ce troisième prêt, 10 cartouches de Cigarettes  de différentes marques,10 paquets de bonbon, 3  cartons du thé, 2 sacs du sucre, 8 paquet de Chewing-gum, 10 paquets d’allumette, 2 cartons de savon, 10 chargeurs supplémentaires, 40 cartes de recharge téléphoniques Orange/Malitel, etc. 
Il achète ses marchandises auprès de commerçants grossistes de place avant de les revendre en détail au comptant à crédit à une clientèle composée de garagistes et de routiers puisque sa tablette est située auprès des garages-auto et de la direction régionale de Douanes de Sikasso, un lieu très fréquenté.
Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 200 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Kaniba F., a polygamous man of 50+ years, is the father of sixteen children who resides with his family in Sanoubougou, the downtown of Sikasso City (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  He is a chauffeur by training.  After twenty years working in this profession in the Republic of Cote d'Ivoire, he ended up returning to the fold when he became introduced about six years ago to small-scale commerce, especially buying and selling cigarettes, candy, matches, chewing gum, milk powder, tea, sugar, soap, and now the transferring of phone credits, the charging of batteries, and the sale of phone cards.  In addition, he represents the company Nationale de Tabacs et Allumettes du Mali (SONATAM SA) in his district.  He is much in demand by his customers for the quality of his products.  To satisfy his burgeoning customer base, Kaniba decided three years ago to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and is now on his third individual loan.  All the preceding ones have been repaid properly.  He plans on using this third loan to buy 10 cartons of cigarettes of different brands, 10 packets of candies, 3 boxes of tea, 2 sacks of sugar, 8 packets of chewing gum, 10 packets of matches, 2 boxes of soap, 10 extra chargers, 10 Orange/Malitel phone recharge cards, etc.  He purchases his merchandise from local wholesale merchants, and he accepts cash or credit from a customer base composed of mechanics and truck drivers, since his tablette is located along with auto garages and with the region management of Sikasso Customs, a very busy place.  With this loan, Kaniba envisions making a monthly profit of 200,000 francs CFA that will be used essentially for helping to cover family expenses, for paying the loan interest, and for investing in his business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying various goods

loans.name: Ousmane

texts.fr:
Né le 25 Juin 1963 à Sikasso ville, Monsieur Ousmane B. est un est polygame avec deux épouses et père de 8 enfants résidant chez lui-même à Hamdallaye, un des quartiers populaires de ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Maître coranique de profession, Monsieur B. après plusieurs années dans l’enseignement, l’abandonna au profit de la photographie et le cameraman qu’il menait en parallèle  à l’enseignement. Avec une expérience de plus de vingt  années dans le domaine, il est très sollicité et jouit d’une notoriété exemplaire pour la qualités de ses images surtout lors des cérémonies de mariages, baptêmes, anniversaires, etc. Il dispose  de son propre studio au quartier Hamdallaye près de camp militaire “TIEBA”. 
Dans le souci de faire prospérer ses affaires afin de mieux répondre aux attentes de ses clients, il décida d’intégrer le programme de crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a environ deux ans. Il est à son deuxième prêt individuel,  le prêt précédent  ayant été correctement remboursé.
 Ce deuxième lui permettra d’acheter un nouvel appareil, des pellicules photo, des cassettes vidéo vierges, des piles, etc. 
Il ambitionne réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 95 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Born on June 25, 1963 in Sikasso, Mr. Ousmane B. lives in a polygamous family; he has two wives and is the father of eight children, all of whom live with him in Hamdallaye, one of the modest districts of the Sikasso (the third administrative region of Mali). His original profession is teaching the Koran. After some years of being a teacher, Mr. B. has decided to switch to photography and video recording, something he had been doing as a side activity before. With over 20 years of experience, he is very much in demand and enjoys a good reputation thanks to the high quality of his recordings, mostly taken during weddings, christenings, birthday parties and so on. He has his own studio in Hamdallaye near the Tieba military base. In order to keep his business going and to better meet the customer demand, about two years ago he decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso. He is now on his second individual loan, having duly repaid his earlier loan. The second loan will allow him to purchase a new camera, photo film, blank video tapes, batteries etc. His goal is to reach an average monthly income of 95,000 West African Francs, which will be used essentially to increase his business capital, contribute to the family budget and pay off the interest on his loan.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing a photo camera and accessories (film, blank tapes, batteries etc)

loans.name: Ngô's Group

texts.en: T. Ngô Thị's main source of income comes from providing waste disposal services in her community. She is a 46-year-old woman living in the town of huyện Yên Phong - tỉnh Bắc Ninh. T. is married and has four school-age children. T. has been in her business for over 13 years and earns approximately 2,800,000 dong (VND) a month. In 2007, T. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. T. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 2,006,000 VND from SEDA which was used to invest in expanding the business. She is now requesting a new loan of 5,152,000 VND which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide the service. This will be her third loan from SEDA. T. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. T. is the leader of a five member group accessing a loan offered by SEDA. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is "Nghiêm Xá nhóm 18 (Nhóm 18)". (20201020092) About the Other Borrowers in the Group: 1. Nguyễn Thị Huề (0) is a 39-year-old woman who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND loan to support her business providing recycling services. 2. Mẫn Thị V. (0) is a 41-year-old woman who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND loan to support her business in the services sector. 3. Nguyễn Thị X. (0) is a 40-year-old woman who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock. 4. Nghiêm Thị H. (0) is a 42-year-old woman who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND loan to support her specialized retail store. 5. Nguyễn Thị T. (0) is a 50-year-old woman who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND loan to support her business providing waste management services. About SEDA: The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders. T. Ngô Thị (20201020092) là 46 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy sống ở thành phố huyện Yên Phong - tỉnh Bắc Ninh. T. là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 5 các thành viên. Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.. Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là Nghiêm Xá nhóm 18 (Nhóm 18). Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ cung cấp các dịch vụ xử lý chất thải cho người dân trong cộng đồng địa phương. T. T. hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 13 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, T. kiếm được khoảng 2.800.000 VND. Vào 2007, T. đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. T. đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 2.006.000 VND từ SEDA. Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng đầu tư mở rộng công việc kinh doanh. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 5.152.000 VND. Khoản vay sẽ là 3rd khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA. Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm: 1. Nguyễn Thị Huề (0) là 39 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là cung cấp dịch vụ tái chế. 2. Mẫn Thị V. (0) là 41 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh trên cơ sở dịch vụ. 3. Nguyễn Thị X. (0) là 40 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc. 4. Nghiêm Thị H. (0) là 42 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hiệu bán lẻ chuyên dụng. 5. Nguyễn Thị T. (0) là 50 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là cung cấp dịch vụ quản lý chất thải. Về SEDA: Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam *Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Eudisa

texts.en: Eudisa B. is 58 years old and proud of the record she and her husband have achieved of growing their fishing business and repaying their loans on time. In order to continue this growth and increase her income, Eudisa has applied for a new loan through ASHI. She will use the loan to catch additional fish to sell in a local wholesale market. Though Eudisa’s small company does not make a lot of money, she takes satisfaction in the fact that she and her husband support their family without help from others. Because of their hard work, one of their children is in college, and she hopes to be able to persuade another, who is 18, to do the same thing.

loans.use: To expand a small fishing business

loans.name: Bring Ambercourt To Unite Group 5, Jinja

texts.en:
With a produce-selling business one is guaranteed a ready market, depending on how persuasive one is. That’s what diligent and affable 30-year-old N. Aisha has found out in her ten years experience running her business. She has, for the most part, been selling cassava, bananas and potatoes.

Aisha’s business in Amber Court market, Jinja, has had its fair share of troubles but Aisha has not buckled under the pressure, knowing what is at stake in reference to her family’s welfare. She has five children to take care of and all her children are in school, though at first glance, her paltry profits of 45,000 shillings a week would make one think she is incapable of handling her family tasks.

Aisha was introduced to her business by a close friend and, like any other business, the start was tough as Aisha did not have sufficient capital to buy all the crops she wanted to sell. With a decade's experience behind her, Aisha's optimism is sky high. At first,she was selling only bananas but, at length, she realized she had to diversify into selling other highly favored foods, too.

Aisha is looking at expanding her business with this loan. That, in essence, means buying produce like bananas, cassava and potatoes that she intends to sell. She is elated that she is going to establish a strong niche for herself after she gets this loan.

loans.use: To buy more produce like bananas, cassava and potatoes to sell

loans.name: Mohamed Jallo Group

texts.en:
Marama J., who we see here holding a sign, leads a group of five borrowers called Mohamed J.. She is 47 years old, widowed and has four children who range in age from 14 to 26 years old. She was not able to attend school due to poverty, and for the last 12 years has made a living selling rice and oil in a local market in Paynesville, a small town which is located on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia. She is good at attracting new customers to her stand because she enjoys talking to people in a friendly manner. She plans to use her 8,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 40,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more bags of rice and more gallons of oil to sell. Marama describes herself as a very peaceful person, and dreams of helping her children have a better future.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, we see loan group member Hawa in an inset at lower right because she was not able to be present at the interview.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice and more gallons of oil to sell to her customers

loans.name: Trần's Group

texts.en:
T. Trần Thị is a 55-year-old woman who lives in the town of Huyện Yên Phong - tỉnh Bắc Ninh. She leads a loan group which has eight members. Each receives a loan, but they all are responsible for paying back the loans of other group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of the group is Đông Mai nhóm 01 (Nhóm 01).

T. is married, has five grown children, and makes a living by running a general store. She has been in this line of work for more than 10 years and earns approximately 3.000.000 VND a month from her work. In 2009, she joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business.  She has successfully repaid a loan for 5.152.000 VND which she used to buy additional products to sell.  She is applying for a new loan for 7.840.000 VND to invest in expanding her business. 

About the Other Borrowers in the Group:
1.  Nguyễn Thị T. (0) is 30 years old and requesting a 7.392.000 VND loan to expand her retail store.

2.  Ngô Thị L. is 31 years old and requesting a 7.392.000 VND loan to expand her furniture-making business.

3.  Nguyễn Thị H. is 25 years old and requesting a 6.944.000 VND loan to support her furniture-making business.

4.  Ngô Thị X. is 45 years sold and requesting a 6.944.000 VND loan to support her service-based business.

5.  Nguyễn Thị H. is 28 years old and requesting a 6.944.000 VND loan to support her furniture-making business.

6.  Nguyễn Thị T. is 46 years old and requesting a 7.392.000 VND loan to support her service-based business.

7.  Nguyễn Thị C. is 37 years old and requesting a 6.944.000 VND loan to support her food stall.

About SEDA:
The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.. 5.  Nguyễn Thị H. (0) là 28 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.944.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực sản xuất.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh chế tạo hàng nội thất.


6.  Nguyễn Thị T. (0) là 46 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 7.392.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh trên cơ sở dịch vụ.


7.  Nguyễn Thị C. (0) là 37 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.944.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm.


Về SEDA:

Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  .

loans.use: to expand a group of small businesses

loans.name: Allah Malanah Group

texts.en:
Jefferson K. leads a group of five borrowers called Allah Malanah. He is 39 years old, married and has two children who are 7 and 11 years old. He was able to attend school only through 12th grade due to lack of financial support, and is proud of the fact that both of his children are still in school.

For the last two years, he has made a living selling slippers and DVDs in Monrovia, Liberia. He plans to use his 6,000 Liberian Dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian Dollar group loan to buy more slippers and DVDs to sell to his customers. His long-term goals are to continue to expand his business, build a store and support his family so that they can have better future.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Jefferson is holding the sign.

loans.use: To buy more slippers and DVDs to sell to his customers

loans.name: Rushuma Twimukye Group, Kihihi

texts.en:
K. Amos, aged 30, with a family of three children, has been operating a retail shop in Itembezo trading centre, Kihihi, for over 5 years. There, he trades in a variety of products commonly used domestically like sugar, soft drinks, sodas, water, cooking oil and much more. In a week, he makes profits amounting to 40,000 shillings. He does this business alongside his other farming practices that include growing and selling tea, sorghum and millet.

Amos’s main drawback is that he has a limited variety of products in his shop that currently cannot satisfy his increasing customer demand. Therefore he is looking forward to increasing the amount of stock in his business when he gets this loan and also to expanding into a wholesale shop. This will help him earn more revenue and sustain his daily life needs.

Amos also belongs to a group of members who insure each other in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To purchase more merchandise for his store like bags of sugar and salt and crates of soft drinks

loans.name: Nguyễn's Group

texts.en:
Tý Nguyễn Thị is 51 years old and lives in the town of huyện Yên Phong - tỉnh Bắc Ninh.  She leads a seven-person L. group. While each member of the group receives an individual L., they are all responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this group is Đông Mai nhóm 02 (Nhóm 02).

Tý is married, has one grown child, and makes a living by raising chickens to sell.  She has been in this business for more than five years and earns approximately 5.000.000 VND a month from her work.

In 2009, Tý joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid a previous L. of 5.152.000 VND from SEDA, and used it to buy more livestock to raise. She is now requesting a new L. of 7.840.000 VND to buy feed and other supplies.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated by this L. to continue expanding her business.

About the Other Borrowers in the Group:
1.  Ngô Thị T. is 45 years old and requesting a 5.152.000 VND L. to support her furniture-making business.

2.  Ngô Thị L. is 26 years old and requesting a 7.392.000 VND L. to support her furniture-making business.

3.  Ngô Thị Phố is 47 years old and requesting a 5.152.000 VND L. to support her furniture-making business.

4.  Nguyễn Thị L. is 29 years old and requesting a 5.152.000 VND L. to support her retail store.

5.  Nguyễn Thị H. is 40 years old and requesting a 6.944.000 VND L. to support her furniture-making business.

6.  Ngô Thị Huệ (0) is 24 years old and requesting a 5.152.000 VND L. to support her furniture-making business.

About SEDA:
The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this L. was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Tý Nguyễn Thị (20211010016) là 51 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố huyện Yên Phong - tỉnh Bắc Ninh.  Tý là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 7 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là Đông Mai nhóm 02 (Nhóm 02).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ chăn nuôi gà để bán.  Tý thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 5 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Tý kiếm được khoảng 5.000.000 VND.  Vào 2009, Tý đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Tý đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 5.152.000 VND từ SEDA.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua gia súc còn nhỏ để nuôi & bán sau này.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 7.840.000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 2nd khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA.

loans.use: to support several small businesses

loans.name: God Is Able Group

texts.en:
Mai N. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called God Is Able. She is 47 years old, single and she has four children who range from 18 to 29 years old. She was only able to attend school through 8th grade due to lack of financial support.

For 11 years Mai has been selling building materials such as zinc, shovels, nails, paint, brushes, steel rods, and so on, at Redlight Market in Paynesville on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 12,000 LRD portion of this 52,000 LRD group loan to buy more building materials.

Her plan is to expand her business, travel abroad, and extend her business contacts and continue to support her family so that they can have a better future.

In the photo Mai is the one holding the sign.

loans.use: To buy more building materials such as zinc, shovels, nails, paint, brushes, steel rods.

loans.name: Omukabare Tukundane Group, Bushenyi

texts.en:
M. Josephat is a hardworking and well-trained entrepreneur who runs a veterinary drug shop alongside his other coffee and banana sales business in Omukabare, Bushenyi. This business has been in place for a period of twenty-five years and has been bringing him dividends close to 50,000 Ugandan shillings on a weekly basis. As a result,he has been able to make ends meet in as far as consolidating his operations.

This married father of eight has worked tirelessly to see to it that his family's fortunes improve every year. With his business, he has given all his children an education. His main drawback, however, all this while, has been having a small amount of stock which has, in a way, hindered the growth and expansion of his business. With this loan, he looks forward to restocking his veterinary drug shop. He figures he will be in a place of vantage to earn more revenue by buying, and later reselling to his clients, additional veterinary drugs.

Josephat is fully upbeat about his future prospects in his business. This he says on the grounds of his track record of hard work.

loans.use: To purchase more drugs for his shop

loans.name: Walid

texts.en:
Walid is a 30-year old man from Lebanon. He currently lives with his parents and sibling. In 2009, he started working as a van taxi driver. He is requesting a loan of $1,500 from Kiva partner A. Majmoua to pay the rent of the van since it is expensive. Unfortunately, Walid doesn't have enough cash to buy a van, therefore he rents it, which in the end costs him a lot.

Walid says that he is well known especially thanks to his punctuality. In the future, he plans on buying his own van.

He will also use some of the loan to purchase aluminum to renovate his house.

loans.use: To pay the rent of the van.

loans.name: Bekmurod

texts.en:
B. Bekmurod is a 36 year-old married man with 4 children. Bekmurod’s goals are to grow in his personal life and in his business. His wish is to offer better service to his customers. His dream is that God continues to provide him with more life to get ahead and to fulfill his goals.

Bekmurod is a taxi driver and travels the streets of Spitamen region in search of customers. At the same time he raises young cattle and sells them at the market with the help of his family.

He has owned his business for 10 years. His car needs thorough repair and for this purpose he wants to borrow 4000 TJS. With part of the loan he’ll purchase young cattle. Bekmurod sincerely thanks Kiva and all lenders that make this help possible.

More about Tajikistan

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchasing spare parts for his car and to buy young cattle.

loans.name: Salimjon

texts.en:
H. Salimjon is 53 and married with one child. He is a very hard-working man who has experienced a great deal throughout his life. For the past three years, he has dedicated himself to providing taxi services. Salimjon is not regretful and is instead very proud of being a taxi driver. It is work where he can be free and make good friends as he is very charismatic. He always has a smile at the ready, and manages to bring out the same from those who ride in his taxi. Happily for Salimjon, business is good. Currently his car needs thorough repair so he wants to borrow 4000 Somoni with which to buy the spare parts needed. He sincerely thanks Kiva and all lenders that make this help possible.

loans.use: to buy spare parts to fix his taxi.

loans.name: Zumrat

texts.en:
S. Zumrat is 53 years old and comes from a large and humble family. She is married and the loving mother of three children. Her father's hard and demanding character showed her, from the time Zumrat was a young girl, the value of work, and therefore she has been successful in various activities throughout her life. Now she dedicates herself to raising and selling cattle, and with the income she generates she provides a better quality of life for her children, who are her greatest joy and have become her best friends. Zumrat asks for a loan of 5600 Somoni in order to buy more young cattle to sell when they are fully grown. With this investment she will be able to substantially grow her earnings and improve her quality of life. Let’s support this dedicated mother's proposal.

loans.use: Purchasing young cows

loans.name: Mahmadburkhon

texts.en:
Since he was very young, Mahmadburkhon has worked in farming. By way of this work, he succeeds in supporting his family, providing his little boy with the education he deserves. He is applying to IMON International for a loan to buy seeds and fertilizer for his crops. Mahmadburkhon hopes that he will be given a loan so that he will succeed in his business and improve his standard of living.

loans.use: Purchasing seed and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Abdujalil

texts.en:
O. Abdujalil is a 44-year-old farmer who lives with his wife and seven children in the southern part of Tajikistan, in the Kumsangir region. Abdujalil has two milk cows and sells dairy products to the local wholesale traders. He also has farm land where he grows vegetables. He has 9 years of experience in his businesses. The milk products are in demand in his village and his orders for them are very high but the milk his cows give is not enough for the traders, so he decided to apply for $3000 USD to purchase an additional cow and fodder as well as seeds and fertilizer. Abdujalil is very grateful to everyone who is helping him improve his standard of living with this loan.

loans.use: Purchasing a cow and farm supplies

loans.name: Parveen's Group

texts.en:
Parveen, a resident of Borewala, the city of shrines in Pakistan, owns a two room house where she been living with her family for over 25 years. Her husband has owned and operated a timber-selling business for the last ten years. He is supported financially by his three sons: one works in a factory on a monthly wage; another is a cobbler, while the youngest is a daily wage laborer.

Parveen, a very good mother taking care of her sons and carring out her responsibilities as a housewife, has taken and repaid two loans from Asasah. She is now applying for a new loan to purchase timber in bulk to expand her husband’s business.

loans.use: Purchase timber to sell

loans.name: United We Stand Group

texts.en:
Kaibeh A., shown holding the sign in the photo, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called United We Stand. She is 38 years old, married and has two children, 10 and 16 years old respectively. She was only able to attend school through 12th grade due to poverty. 

Since one year ago, she has been selling soft drinks and juices at Redlight Market on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia. She says customers get attracted to her business because she talks to them in a friendly manner.

She plans to use her 8,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 40,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more crates of soft drinks and juices. She describes herself as a very peaceful person.

Her dream is to grow her business, educate her children and improve her standard of living.

loans.use: To buy more crates of soft drinks and juices.

loans.name: Abida Rani's Group

texts.en:
Abida Rani is a wife of M. A. and lives in Borewala, city of shrines, in Pakistan. She has lived in a small house of two rooms with her family for twenty years. Her husband has been involved in the timber selling business for over five years.  

Abida is a seamstress.  She is very skillful in her work. She works for neighborhood clients and receives reasonable income. Her sewing business helps her to share the financial burden with her husband for the family. She has one daughter who reads in the 5th standard. Abida and her husband want to give their daughter a good education to make her future bright and to make them proud.  

She has successfully repaid her two loans to Asasah (microfinance institute in Pakistan and a partner of Kiva) and now is applying for the third time. She will use the funds to invest the loan capital in her husband’s business so that he can expand his business by buying timber in bulk. 

Note: "Abida and her group member Asia both operate domestic sewing businesses".

loans.use: To purchase timber to sell.

loans.name: Kankalay Group

texts.en:
These are the members of Kankalay Group. They are small-scale businesswomen in the small town of Waterloo who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva, to apply for a loan of SLL 500,000 each. With the help of this loan, these entrepreneurs will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and make better profits. 

Sarah K. is the leader of this group. She was born in Bo, a city in southern Sierra Leone. She is 43 years of age, married to a military officer, and they have six children.

Sarah sells rice, sugar, palm-oil (the country’s most popular cooking oil), etc., and she has been running this business for six years now. With the help of this loan, Sarah will expand her business by buying the above mentioned items wholesale to add to her current inventory.

loans.use: To buy more rice, sugar and palm-oil wholesale

loans.name: Madina Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are the members of the “Madina” group from Waterloo, a small-town in Western Sierra Leone. They are petty businesswomen who have come to SMT, a Kiva partner, in order to seek a loan of SLL 500,000 each. With this loan, they will be able to add more goods to their businesses, attract more customers, make more sales and profit, and consequently improve on their living conditions.

The leader of this group of entrepreneurs is Ya Bora K.. Ya Bora was born in Waterloo 65 years ago. She is married and has three children. Her husband is a local chief and her children are now grown-ups and living on their own.

Ya Bora sells sticks (used for building houses/structures, fences, etc.). She also sells cold water. She has been in this business for six years now. With her share of the loan, she will buy dozens of sticks to add to her inventory.

loans.use: To buy dozens of sticks to add to her inventory

loans.name: Anna

texts.en:
Anna K. is currently in the business of selling green vegetables and fruits like mangoes, gavva etc at the market and is requesting a loan to stock persimmon fruits and pears to sell.  Anna is 41 years old and is married. Her husband is a major in the army. She has 4 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a pub.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock persimmon fruits and pears to sell.

loans.name: Eligathe

texts.en:
Eligathe J. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and fire woods at her home and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell.  Eligathe is 47 years old. She is married and her husband is a retired director. She has 4 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a motor bike to transport bags of charcoal from producers to the retailing markets.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more bags of charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Betteh Dae Group

texts.en:
Fatmata C. is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. She was born in Waterloo small-town about 40 years ago. She is married to a driver and the couple has two children, one in Senior Secondary School VI (SSS VI) and the other in SSS IV.

For eight years now, Fatmata C. has been selling clothes. With the help of this loan, she will be able to expand her business and make more sales, consequently improving on her living conditions. She will use her loan of SLL 1,000,000 to further expand her business; she will buy clothes wholesale to add to her current inventory.

loans.use: To buy more clothes wholesale to add to her inventory

loans.name: Asumpata

texts.en:
Asumpata K is currently in the business of selling Irish potatoes and cassava tubers at the market. She is requesting a loan to stock hens and cocks to sell. Asumpata is 38 years old and is married. Her husband is a soldier. She has 4 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a restaurant.
